abstract.p: A method for dynamic analysis of a torsionally coupled structure isolated with variable friction pendulum system (VFPS) (an advanced friction base isolator recently developed by the authors) is demonstrated. As the name suggests, the novelty of the VFPS is its variation of the friction coefficient at the sliding interface. The friction coefficient of the VFPS is such that up to a certain value of the isolator displacement it increases and then it decreases with a further increase in the isolator displacement. Six pairs of near-fault ground motions are selected as input ground motions in the study. The analysis considers the effects of the interaction developed between the frictional forces in the two principal directions due to sliding of the individual VFPS isolator. In order to investigate the effectiveness of the base isolation using the VFPS, the coupled lateral-torsional response is obtained under different parametric variations by employing Newmark's step-by-step method assuming linear variation of acceleration over a small time interval. The effectiveness of the base isolation using the VFPS is quantified with the help of the response ratio between the peak responses of the torsionally coupled structure with and without the VFPS. Moreover, the behavior of the structure isolated by the VFPS has been compared with the same structure isolated using the conventional friction pendulum system (FPS) and the double concave friction pendulum (DCFP) bearing. The numerical results of the extensive parametric study help in understanding the torsional behavior of the structure isolated with the VFPS under near-fault ground motions. It is also found that the VFPS behaves remarkably better than the FPS in controlling the torsional response for all types of torsional systems. The VFPS is also superior to the DCFP for torsionally flexible systems, whereas the behavior of the VFPS is nearly identical to that of the DCFP for torsionally rigid systems.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The traditional method of providing earthquake resistance to a structure is by increasing its strength as well as its energy absorbing capacity. However, during an earthquake many structures have suffered structural and non-structural damage due to inelastic deformation (Rai, 2000). An alternative method known as base isolation is today an accepted design philosophy for earthquake resistant design of structural systems and sensitive instruments. For a few decades, the use of the base isolation technique has achieved significant success in reducing the structural damage to buildings from earthquake attacks (Nagarajaiah and Sun, 2000; Wu and Samali, 2002). The main concept in a base isolation system is to isolate the structure from the ground by using isolators between the base of the structure and its foundation. These base isolators have two important characteristics: horizontal flexibility and energy absorbing capacity. Horizontal flexibility lowers the fundamental frequency of the structure below the range of frequencies which dominate in general earthquake excitation. Energy absorbing capacity reduces both the relative displacements and the seismic energy that are transmitted to the structure. Among various base isolation systems, the sliding bearings are the most widely adopted due to their insensitivity to the frequency content of earthquake excitation. The other advantage of sliding bearings is that it ensures the maximum acceleration transmissibility equal to the maximum limiting frictional force. Several sliding base isolation systems, such as the friction pendulum system (FPS) (Zayas et al., 1990), the variable frequency pendulum isolator (VFPI) (Pranesh and Sinha, 2004), the double concave friction pendulum (DCFP) bearing (Fenz and Constantinou, 2006), the triple friction pendulum bearing (Fenz and Constantinou, 2008), the friction controllable sliding isolation system (Nagarajaiah et al., 1993a), and a new semi-active independently variable friction (SAIVF) device (Narasimhan and Nagarajaiah, 2006) have been proposed and investigated in the past. An excellent review of the base-isolation concepts and applications is published in the literature (Buckle and Mayes, 1990; Kelly, 1986; Naeim and Kelly, 1999).

In spite of the direct benefits of the seismic isolation technology, some researchers have suggested that base-isolated buildings can be vulnerable to large pulse-like ground motions generated at near-fault locations (Hall et al., 1995; Heaton et al., 1995). Also, there have been other publications that have warned about the vulnerability of base-isolated structures to near-fault ground motions, known as ‘epicentral acceleration records' (Tena-Colunga, 1996; Tena-Colunga et al., 1997), including those that have used epicentral (near-fault) ground motion records to study the torsional response of base-isolated structures (Tena-Colunga and Gomez-Soberon, 2002; Tena-Colunga and Zambrana-Rojas, 2006; Tena-Colunga and Escamilla-Cruz, 2007). Further, there has been some interesting work recently published in the torsional response of frictional systems (De la Llera et al., 2005). Near-fault ground motions can be quite different than those from the far-fault events. In particular, records of such ground motions can contain large long-period spectral components in the fault normal direction, large short-period spectral components in the fault parallel direction, long-duration pulses of ground displacement and high peak ground velocities (Jangid and Kelly, 2001). These higher spectral inputs, occurring in the neighborhood of important structural periods, can result in a seismic response significantly greater than what would occur in a typical far-fault design level event. In such astrong response, the particularly large isolator displacement will lead to the requirement of very large isolators, costly flexible connections for utilities, and an extensive and expensive loss of space for a seismic gap. Moreover, if the seismic gap is inadequate to accommodate such large isolator displacements, then the resulting impact response can be undesirable (Nagarajaiah and Sun, 2001). The solution to control the isolator displacements for large input level earthquakes while maintaining good performance for low-to-moderate level earthquakes was suggested by Kelly (1999). Kelly believed that this can be achieved either by gradually increasing the curvature of the spherical surface of the isolator or increasing the roughness of the sliding surface of the isolator. Thus, an attempt is made in the present study to control the isolator displacement of the torsionally coupled base-isolated structures adjacent to an active earthquake fault by using the variable friction pendulum system (VFPS) (a new friction base isolator recently developed by the authors).

Many investigations have been carried out on base-isolated structures. Most of the analytical works on base isolation of buildings deal with two-dimensional (2-D) idealization, which is strictly valid for symmetric buildings. In practice, symmetrical buildings are rare and most buildings are unsymmetrical to some extent, due to either an unsymmetrical plan, or unsymmetrical elevation, or unsymmetrical distribution of vertical members, or unsymmetrical mass distribution on the floors. Compared with the buildings with symmetric configuration, such buildings due to torsional coupling are more susceptible to damage, especially under seismic loads. It is the most important factor that differentiates between three-dimensional (3-D) and 2-D idealization of the building and can result in significant response amplifications. Excessive edge deformation due to torsional coupling may cause pounding between closely spaced adjacent buildings. Torsional coupling has been identified as one of the major causes of poor performance or failure of buildings during earthquakes. The recognition of this fact has led several researchers to focus their study on the earthquake behavior of such systems (Agrawal, 2000; Eisenberger and Rutenberg, 1986; Goel and Chopra, 1990; Jangid and Datta, 1994a, 1994b, 1995; Lee, 1980; Nagarajaiah et al., 1991, 1993b, 1993c; Pan and Kelly, 1983; Pranesh and Sinha, 2004; Samali et al., 2003). These reviews clearly show that so far, there have not been many attempts to investigate the behavior of torsionally coupled structures isolated with friction base isolators, especially under near-fault ground motions. In view of the above, numerical studies are carried out to understand the torsional behavior of structures isolated with the VFPS under bi-directional near-fault ground motions.

Herein, an analysis for the response of a 3-D one-story model of a building isolated with the VFPS has been presented. The standard analysis for 3-D response has been modified to account for variation of the friction coefficient at the sliding surface of the VFPS. The responses are obtained for a wide range of parametric studies by employing Newmark's step-by-step method. The main objectives of the study are: (1) to examine the behavior of a torsionally coupled structure isolated with the VFPS under near-fault ground motions; (2) to investigate the effectiveness of the base isolation using the VFPS for a torsionally coupled structure under a set of important parametric variations; and (3) to compare the seismic response of a torsionally coupled structure isolated with the VFPS, the FPS and the DCFP in order to measure the effectiveness of the VFPS.

sec.title: 2. Variable friction pendulum system
sec.p: The authors (Panchal and Jangid, 2008a, 2008b, 2009) have recently developed a new isolator, called a variable friction pendulum system (VFPS). Authors investigated the installation of the VFPS in structures; a significant reduction in the peak isolator displacement (around 45% to 60%) was found in comparison to the FPS under the normal component of near-fault ground motions. Therefore, the VFPS is quite effective in controlling large isolator displacement and providing the adaptive behavior for the structures adjacent to an active earthquake faults.

The difference between the VFPS and the FPS (Zayas et al., 1990) is that the friction coefficient of the VFPS is varied in the form of a curve whereas the friction coefficient of the FPS is considered to be constant as shown in Figure 1. This innovative feature of the VFPS makes it a robust and superior friction isolator. The selected variation of the friction coefficient is such that up to a certain value of the isolator displacement the frictional force increases and then it decreases with further increase in the isolator displacement. This type of variation gives the isolator initial softness for smaller inputs, then provides stiffness for moderate inputs, and finally for large inputs it again becomes soft. Such pattern of variation is selected with the criterion that the isolator displacement and building base shear decrease significantly without much alteration to the superstructure acceleration under near-fault ground motions (Panchal and Jangid, 2008a). If the curve with high friction at large magnitudes of ground shaking is used, it will result in significant reduction in isolator displacement, but at the expense of significant increases in superstructure acceleration and base shear. In other words, high values of friction coefficient at large magnitudes of ground shaking nullify the primary reasons for using base isolation, viz. the reduction of superstructure acceleration and base shear. Therefore, by selecting the above curve, a compromise is made between the isolator displacement and the superstructure acceleration. Figure 1.
Comparison between the friction coefficient of the friction pendulum system and the variable friction pendulum system.

The desired variation in the frictional coefficient of the VFPS can be achieved by changing the roughness of the spherical sliding surface (Hwang and Zum Gahr, 2003; Kurtus, 2008). However, practically, it is not easy to achieve this transition and in this study a mathematical idealization has been used for the variation of the friction coefficient. Experimental evaluation of seismic performance of structures isolated by the VFPS has not been carried out yet. sec.title: 3. Double concave friction pendulum (DCFP) bearing
sec.p: The characteristics of the FPS can be made more effective by introducing a second sliding surface. This device is called a double concave friction pendulum (DCFP) bearing (Fenz and Constantinou, 2006). Since sliding is possible on both concave surfaces, the displacement capacity of a DCFP bearing is substantially larger than that of a traditional FPS of identical plan dimensions. This is the principal benefit of DCFP bearing as compared to FPS. This key feature of the behavior results in significant savings in terms of material cost of the isolators. There are four parameters (two radii and two friction coefficients) that can be varied rather than just two (radius and friction coefficient) as with the traditional FPS, thereby offering more options to optimize performance. These possibilities can be exploited to improve performance for near-source excitations. Moreover, there is the possibility of using upper and lower concave surfaces with different radii of curvature and coefficient of friction. The behavior of the DCFP is tri-linear for different radii of curvatures and coefficients of friction of two sliding surfaces whereas it exhibits bi-linear behavior for the same friction coefficient and radii of curvatures.

The DCFP bearing with sliding surfaces of different displacement capacitiescan also achieve the adaptive behavior similar to the triple friction pendulum bearing (Fenz and Constantinou, 2008). In other words, one surface having low friction and small radius paired with another surface of large radius and higher friction offers better re-centering capabilities for weak excitations but still has sufficient flexibility and energy dissipation capability for stronger excitations. Therefore, the time period and the coefficient of friction of the top and bottom bearing of the DCFP are selected as 2.0 sec, 0.055 and 1.5 sec, 0.041, respectively, giving a combined time period, Tc equal to 2.5 sec and combined friction coefficient, μc equal to 0.05. The combined time period Tc and combined coefficient of friction μc of the DCFP disregarding the effect of the small mass of the slider can be expressed as (10) (11) where T1 and T2 are the time period of top and bottom sliding surfaces; and μ1 and μ2 are the coefficients of friction of top and bottom sliding surfaces.

sec.title: 4. Mathematical model
sec.p:
Figure 2(a) represents the assumed structural system, which is an idealized one-story building model mounted on the VFPS isolators. The superstructure of the system consists of a rigid deck slab and columns. The lateral dimension of the deck slab is d in x-direction and b in y-direction. The rigid deck slab is supported at the edges by massless, axially inextensible columns and the columns are connected to a rigid base slab. The CM is located at the geometrical center of the deck slab, as the columns are modeled as massless and column masses are included in the slab mass. Each column has the same stiffness in the two principal directions. The stiffness distribution of the columns is symmetric about the x-axis but not about the y-axis; as a result, the structure displays a torsional effect when excited in the lateral direction-y. The system of isolators consists of an array of the VFPS isolators arranged between the foundation and the rigid base slab. These isolators arefixed to the foundation at the bottom and to the base slab at the top. The following assumptions apply for the model under study.
The structure above the VFPS isolators is assumed to be linear and elastic. This is a reasonable assumption since the purpose of base isolation is to reduce the earthquake's effects so that the columns of the superstructure remain within the elastic range.
The superstructure will slide over the VFPS isolators without tilting or overturning.
Although a torsional moment develops at each isolator, the contribution of this torsional moment to the total torque exerted at the base mass is insignificant and hence is not included.
The VFPS isolator carries the vertical load without undergoing any vertical deformation.
The friction coefficient of the VFPS is assumed to be independent of the relative velocity at the sliding interface. This is based on the findings that such effects do not have noticeable effects on the peak response of the isolated structural system (Fan et al., 1990).
Restoring force provided by the VFPS is consideredto be linear (i.e., proportional to relative displacement).
The VFPS is isotropic (i.e., there is the same isolation period and the coefficient of friction in each of the two principal directions of the motion in the horizontal plane).
The fault normal and parallel components of near-fault ground motions are applied in two horizontal directions (i.e., x- and y-directions, respectively) of the building isolated with the VFPS.

Note that the equation indicates the circular interaction between the frictional forces mobilized in the two principal directions. The frictional forces mobilized in the VFPS are nonlinear functions of the displacement and velocity of the system in two orthogonal directions. Also, during the sliding phase of motion, the mobilized frictional forces are coupled with each other by the circular interaction. As a result, the coupled differential equations of motion (equations (20) and (21)) are solved in the incremental form by employing Newmark's step-by-step method assuming linear variation of acceleration over the short time interval, Δt. The maximum time interval for solving the equations of motion is taken as 0.02/20 sec (i.e., Δt = 0.001 sec).

sec.title: 7. Parametric study
sec.p: The response of a torsionally coupled structure isolated with the VFPS to the near-fault ground motions is investigated with respect to the following parameters: uncoupled time period of the superstructure, Tx, ratio of uncoupled torsional to lateral frequencies of the superstructure, ωθ/ωx, uncoupled torsional to lateral frequencies of the isolator, ωbθ/ωb, eccentricity ratio of the superstructure, ex/d, isolator eccentricity, ebx/d, mass ratio, mb/m, initial time period of the VFPS, Ti and isolation period, Tb. The important parameters justmentioned predominantly influence the torsional coupling and base isolation characteristics. Therefore, the range of these parameters was carefully selected in order to obtain a better understanding of the influence of the system parameters on torsional coupling. The specifications for the values of the other parameters (which are held constant throughout) are: lateral dimension, b=d=10.0m; number of the VFPS isolators is 4; and modal damping for the superstructure is taken as 5% of the critical damping for all modes.

Six set of near-fault ground motions are used as input ground motions in order to study the dynamic behavior of a torsionally coupled structure isolated with the VFPS. Some characteristics of the selected ground motions, such as duration, PGA, PGV and PGD are summarized in Table 1. From this table, it is found that these near-fault ground motions have a variety of PGA, PGV and PGD. In order to give further insight into the near-fault ground motions, the pulse characteristics of normal component of selected near-fault ground motions are summarized in Table 2. This table reveals that the normal component of near-fault ground motions covers an equivalent velocity pulse period ranging from 0.75 sec to 5 sec and velocity pulse amplitude range from 0.6 m/sec to 1.75 m/sec. The trigonometric cycloidal pulses mentioned in the table were developed by Makris and Chang (2000) to approximate the selected near-fault ground motions. In most of the ground motions, the peak ground acceleration of fault normal component is relatively higher than that of fault parallel component. The acceleration and displacement spectra of the six ground motions for 5% damping are shown in Figure 3. The spectra of these ground motions indicate that the ground motions are recorded at a firm soil or rock site. For low periods (i.e., in the range 0–0.3 sec), the average spectral acceleration and displacement values of the fault normal and parallel component is almost the same. For longer periods (i.e., beyond 0.3 sec), the spectral acceleration and displacement component of fault normal component is significantly larger than the fault parallel component. Table 1.

sec.title: 7.1. Effect of superstructure eccentricity
sec.p:
The superstructure stiffness eccentricity ex/d is the most important parameter that causes torsional coupling and torsional motions. Figure 4 is plotted to show the effects of superstructure eccentricity on the average base displacements in a torsionally coupled structure isolated with the FPS (Tb = 2.5 sec and μ = 0.05), the VFPS (Tb = 2.5 sec, Ti = 1.5 sec and μmax = 0.15) and the DCFP (Tc = 2.5 sec and μc = 0.05) under six selected near-fault ground motions. The superstructure eccentricity is varied from a symmetric case, ex/d=0 to an asymmetric case, ex/d=0.4. The study has been carried out for four uncoupled frequency ratios of the superstructure: 0.8, 1.0, 1.5 and 2.0. These frequency ratios typically represent a torsionally flexible system to a torsionally stiff system. These frequency ratios encompass the variety of structures prone to torsional motions. It is clearly apparent from the figure that translational base displacements in the VFPS are much lower than in the FPS and the DCFP for all values of the torsional to lateral frequency ratio of the superstructure and superstructure eccentricity. Also, the rotational base displacements in the VFPS are considerably lower than those of the FPS for all types of torsional systems and those of the DCFP for torsionally flexible systems. However, these base displacements in the VFPS are more or less identical to the DCFP for torsionally rigid systems. As base displacements depend on the isolator displacements, it can be said that under near-fault ground motions, the isolator displacements can be controlled within a desirable range using the VFPS. For all isolators considered for the study, the values of base displacements ubx and uby are more or less the same for all values of eccentricity and uncoupled frequency ratio. On the other hand, increasing superstructure eccentricity leads to amplification of base displacement dubθ; however this amplification diminishes with increasing superstructure torsional to lateral frequency ratio. Figure 4.
Variation of the average base displacements of the torsionally coupled structure isolated with the friction pendulum system (Tb = 2.5 sec, μ = 0.05), the variable friction pendulum system (Tb = 2.5 sec, Ti = 1.5 sec, μmax = 0.15) and the double concave friction pendulum (Tc = 2.5 sec, μc = 0.05) against eccentricity for six selected near-fault ground motions; Tx = 1, mb/m = 1.5, ωbθ/ωb = 1 and ebx/d = 0.

Figure 5 shows the effects of asymmetry on the torsional response considering variation of peak average base torque against superstructure eccentricity for six selected near-fault ground motions. The response quantities of interest are shown for a fixed-base structure and structures isolated with the FPS, the VFPS and the DCFP. In the results shown, the same frequency ratios of 0.8, 1.0, 1.5 and 2.0 have been considered in order to cover the practical range of torsional stiffness. From this figure, it is seen that, as expected in all cases, the base torque increases with an increase in the superstructure eccentricity, and it is worth noting that for reducing the base torque, the VFPS behaves better than the FPS and the DCFP for all values of the frequency ratio. This implies that the FPS and the DCFP transmit higher base torque than the VFPS. It is further observed that there is substantial reduction in the torque for all isolated structures in comparison with the fixed-base structure. This figure illustrates how the VFPS is effective in comparison with the FPS and the DCFP in reducing the torsional response of isolated structures. Figure 5.
Effect of lack of symmetry on the average torsional response of the structure subjected to six selected near-fault ground motions.

In order to study the effectiveness of the base isolation using the VFPS, it is convenient to express the response in terms of the ratio rather than plotting their values. For this purpose, a response ratio R is defined as (30)

The response ratio R is an index of the performance of the base isolation using the VFPS and the value less than one indicates that the base isolation using the VFPS is effective. Figure 6 portrays the effect of eccentricity ex/d on the response ratio R and the base displacements in the presence of a variety of system parameters for several near-fault ground motions. The ratio R for the response ux and the displacement ubx which are parallel to the direction of eccentricity, are not influenced by the eccentricity. The ratio R for the response uy increases with an increase in the eccentricity. The same observations hold good for the variation of the ratio R for the response uθ. This indicates that the torsional coupling increases the lateral response of the superstructure perpendicular to the direction of eccentricity. Thus, the effectiveness of the base isolation using the VFPS for an asymmetric system is overestimated if the eccentricity is ignored. The base displacement uby moderately decreases with an increase in ex/d. It is worth noting that the base torsion increases with an increase in the eccentricity. Figure 6.
Effect of ex/d on the response ratio R and the base displacements for the system isolated with the variable friction pendulum system; Tx = 1 sec, ωθ/ωx = 1, mb/m = 1.5, ωbθ/ωb = 1, Tb = 2.5 sec, Ti = 1.5 sec, μmax = 0.15 and ebx/d = 0.

sec.title: 7.2. Effect of torsional to lateral frequency ratio of the superstructure
sec.p:
The ratio of uncoupled torsional frequency to uncoupled lateral frequency is an important parameter in the behavior of asymmetric buildings; that is, it highly influences the response of such systems (Shakib and Datta, 1993). In order to evaluate the effect of ωθ/ωx on the response ratio R and base displacements, Figure 7 is presented for the eccentricity ratio ebx/d=0.15. The ratio R for response ux is insensitive to the variation of the ωθ/ωx ratio. The ratio for response uy decreases with an increase inωθ/ωx (up to ωθ/ωx=1.5) showing an increase in the effectiveness of the base isolation for the response uy. As ωθ/ωx increases (in the range of0.8≤ωθ/ωx≤1), the ratio R for response uθ decreases significantly, showing the effectiveness of the base isolation using VFPS in reducing the torsional response. It is to be noted that the ratio R for the responses uyand uθ remain almost insensitive to the variation of the ωθ/ωx ratio beyond 1.5. This is expected because for a torsionally stiff system (ωθ/ωx≫1) the effect of torsional coupling is considerably reduced. As a result, R for uy and uθ become insensitive to the variation of ωθ/ωx. Further, the base responses are not greatly influenced by the variation of ωθ/ωx. Figure 7.
Effect of ωθ/ωx on the response ratio R and the base displacements for the system isolated with the variable friction pendulum system; Tx = 1 sec, ex/d = 0.15, mb/m = 1.5, ωbθ/ωb = 1, Tb = 2.5 sec, Ti = 1.5 sec, μmax = 0.15 and ebx/d = 0.15.

sec.title: 7.3. Effect of mass ratio
sec.p:
Figure 8 depicts the variation of response ratio R and the base displacements against mb/m for various near-fault ground motions. The response ratio R for ux, uy and uθ increases with the increase in mb/m. As the base mass increases, the limiting value of frictional force in the VFPS increases (see equation (8)). As a result, the system enters into fewer sliding phases, resulting in less dissipation of seismic energy. Thus, the effectiveness of the base isolation using the VFPS decreases with an increase in the mb/m. Further, the base displacements ubx and uby are not much influenced by the variation of mb/m. The base torsion moderately decreases with an increase in the mb/m. Figure 8.
Effect of mb/m on the response ratio R and the base displacements for the system isolated with the variable friction pendulum system; Tx = 1 sec, ex/d = 0.15, ωθ/ωx = 1, ωbθ/ωb = 1, Tb = 2.5 sec, Ti = 1.5 sec, μmax = 0.15 and ebx/d = 0.

sec.title: 7.4. Effect of uncoupled time period of superstructure
sec.p:
In Figure 9, the response ratio R and the base displacements are plotted against the uncoupled time period, Tx, which is considered as a parameter to denote the flexibility of the superstructure. The response ratio R increases with an increase in Tx as shown in Figure 9. Thus, the effectiveness of the base isolation using the VFPS decreases with an increase in the Tx. Further, the base displacements ubx and uby decrease as the superstructure becomes more flexible, whereas the base torsion increases. Figure 9.
Effect of Tx on the response ratio R and base displacements for the system isolated with the variable friction pendulum system; ex/d = 0.15, ωθ/ωx = 1, mb/m = 1.5, ωbθ/ωb = 1, Tb = 2.5 sec, Ti = 1.5 sec, μmax = 0.15 and ebx/d = 0.

sec.title: 7.5. Effect of isolation time period
sec.p:
In order to assess the effect of an isolation period of the VFPS, the variation of the response ratio R and the base displacements are displayed in Figure 10 against the isolation period. It is found that the response ratio R for ux, uy and uθ decreases with the increase in the isolation period of the VFPS. This implies that the effectiveness of the base isolation using the VFPS increases with an increase in the isolation period of the VFPS. On the other hand, the translational base displacements increase as the isolation period of the VFPS increases whereas the base rotation ubθ decreases. Figure 10.
Effect of Tb on the response ratio R and the base displacements for the system isolated with the variable friction pendulum system; Tx = 1 sec, ex/d = 0.15, ωθ/ωx = 1, mb/m = 1.5, ωbθ/ωb = 1, Ti = 1.5 sec, μmax = 0.15 and ebx/d = 0.

sec.title: 7.6. Effect of initial time period of the VFPS
sec.p:
Figure 11 reveals the variation of the response ratio R and the base displacements against the initial time period of the VFPS under different near-fault ground motions. It is evident from the figure that the ratio R and base displacements first decrease, attain a minimum value, and then increase with an increase of the initial time period. This implies that there exists a particular value of the initial time period (i.e., optimum initial time period) for which the ratio R and base displacements attain a minimum value under near-fault ground motions. For the present model of the one-story building and selected near-fault ground motions, the optimum initial time period of the VFPS is found in the vicinity of 1.5 sec. Thus, the effectiveness of the base isolation using the VFPS first increases, attains a minimum value, and then decreases with an increase of its initial time period. Figure 11.
Effect of Ti on the response ratio R and the base displacements for the system isolated with the variable friction pendulum system; Tx = 1 sec, ex/d = 0.15, ωθ/ωx = 1, mb/m = 1.5, ωbθ/ωb = 1, Tb = 2.5 sec, μmax = 0.15 and ebx/d = 0.

sec.title: 7.7. Effect of torsional to lateral frequency ratio of the isolator
sec.p:
The variation of the response ratio R and the base displacements against ωbθ/ωbis demonstrated in Figure 12 for an asymmetric isolator (i.e., ebx/d=0.15). The response ratio R for ux remains insensitive to a variation of ωbθ/ωb. On the other hand, the response ratio R for response uy decreases (in the range of ωbθ/ωb≤1) as ωbθ/ωb increases. But, beyond that it increases with the increase in ωbθ/ωb. The ratio R for torsional response uθ is not much influenced by ωbθ/ωb (in the range of ωbθ/ωb≤1). But, beyond that it decreases with an increase in ωbθ/ωb. The base displacements ubx and uby are virtually unaffected by ωbθ/ωb. However, the base rotation ubθ is significantly influenced by ωbθ/ωb leading to maximum amplification at ωbθ/ωb=1. Figure 12.
Effect of ωbθ/ωb on the response ratio R and the base displacements for the system isolated with the variable friction pendulum system; Tx = 1 sec, ex/d = 0.15, ωθ/ωx = 1, mb/m = 1.5, Tb = 2.5 sec, Ti = 1.5 sec, μmax = 0.15 and ebx/d = 0.15.

sec.title: 7.8. Effect of isolator eccentricity
sec.p:
Figure 13 exhibits the effects of the isolator eccentricity ebx/d on response ratio R and base displacements for various near-fault ground motions. The ratio R for ux remains almost the same for all values of ebx/d, while that for response uy decreases mildly with an increase in ebx/d. However, R for uθ is significantly influenced by ebx/d and increases with the increase of isolator eccentricity. Thus, the effectiveness of the base isolation using the VFPS (in reducing the torsional response of the superstructure) decreases with the increase in isolator eccentricity. The base displacement ubx is found to be insensitive to the variation of ebx/d. On the other hand, the base displacement uby moderately decreases with the increase in ebx/d whereas the base torsion significantly increases. Figure 13.
Effect of ebx/d on the response ratio R and the base displacements for the system isolated with the variable friction pendulum system; Tx = 1 sec, ex/d = 0.15, ωθ/ωx = 1, mb/m = 1.5, ωbθ/ωb = 1, Tb = 2.5 sec, Ti =1.5 sec and μmax = 0.15.

sec.title: 7.9. Effect of angle of incidence
sec.p:
In Figure 14, the variation of the response ratio R and the base displacements is plotted against the angle of incidence, α for several near-fault ground motions. The figure indicates that the response ratio R and the base displacements are moderately influenced by the angle of incidence of ground acceleration with respect to the principal direction of the structure. Figure 14.
Effect of α on the response ratio R and base displacements for the system isolated with the variable friction pendulum system; Tx = 1 sec, ex/d = 0.15, ωθ/ωx = 1, mb/m = 1.5, ωbθ/ωb = 1, Tb = 2.5 sec, Ti = 1.5 sec, μmax = 0.15 and ebx/d = 0.

sec.title: 7.10. Corner displacement magnification as a function of various system parameters
sec.p:
As the deck corner displacement on the flexible side of a building has been very crucial for design purposes, this response quantity has also been given due attention. The deck corner displacement provides the magnitude of deformation due to the combined effect of translation and torsion. By investigating the extent of magnification of deck corner displacement in comparison with the displacement at the center of mass of the deck, the effect of torsional coupling can be qualitatively evaluated. For this purpose, the corner displacement magnification (Nagarajalah et al., 1993a) is utilized. It is defined as the ratio of peak deck corner displacement (relative to base) to peak displacement at the CM (relative to base). Figure 15 demonstrates the variation of deck corner displacement magnification against various system parameters. From this figure it is clearly observed that corner displacement magnification increases with the increase in the superstructure eccentricity and the isolation time period of the VFPS, whereas it mildly decreases with the increase in the torsional to lateral frequency ratio of the superstructure. On the other hand, it first increases, attains a maximum value, and then decreases with the increase in the initial time period of the VFPS. The optimum initial time period for which the corner displacement magnification attains a maximum value is also found to be in the vicinity of 1.5 sec. Figure 15.
Variation of the deck corner displacement magnification against various system parameters.

sec.title: 8. Conclusions
sec.p:
The nonlinear response of a torsionally coupled system isolated with a variable friction pendulum system (VFPS) (a new friction base isolator recently developed by the authors) to bi-directional near-fault ground motions is obtained by considering the interaction of frictional forces in two orthogonal directions. The response behavior of the torsionally coupled system is studied for a set of important parametric variations. The comparison is made between the seismic response of a torsionally coupled structure isolated with the VFPS, the FPS and the DCFP in order to measure the effectiveness of the VFPS. The following conclusions may be drawn from the trend of numerical results of the present study:
For all values of the superstructure eccentricity and the torsional to lateral frequency ratio of the superstructure, the VFPS is significantly better than the FPS and the DCFP for reducing the translational base displacements.
For controlling the torsional base response, the VFPS behaves remarkably better than that of the FPS for all types of torsional systems. It is also superior to the DCFP for torsionally flexible systems, whereas the behavior of the VFPS is nearly identical to that of the DCFP for torsionally rigid systems.
The performance of the VFPS is quite effective in controlling the base torque as compared to that of the FPS and the DCFP under near-fault ground motions.
Under near-fault ground motions, the response ratio for superstructure displacement perpendicularto thedirection of eccentricity increases with the increase in the superstructure eccentricity. Thus, the effectiveness of the base isolation (usingthe VFPS) is overestimated, if the eccentricity of thebuilding is ignored and modeled as a 2-D system.
Under near-fault ground motions, the response ratio for torsional deformation of the superstructure increases with the increase in the superstructure eccentricity showing that the effectiveness of the base isolation (using the VFPS) in reducing torsional response is reduced with the increase in the superstructure eccentricity.
Under near-fault ground motions, the superstructure eccentricity reduces the translational response of base, uby, and increases the torsional response of base, ubθ.
There exists a particular value of the initial time period (i.e., optimum initial time period) for which the effectiveness of the base isolation (using the VFPS) and base displacements attain a minimum value under near-fault ground motions.
For the present model of the one-story building and selected near-fault ground motions, the optimum initial time period of the VFPS is found to be in the vicinity of 1.5 sec under near-fault ground motions.
Under near-fault ground motions, the effectiveness of the base isolation (using the VFPS) decreases with the increase in the mass ratio mb/m and uncoupled time period of superstructure Tx, whereas it increases with the increase in the isolation period Tb.
Under near-fault ground motions, the effectiveness of the base isolation (using the VFPS) in reducing torsional response significantly increases with an increase in ωθ/ωx (i.e., up to ωθ/ωx≈1.0).
An increase in the isolator's eccentricity tends to reduce the effectiveness of the base isolation (using the VFPS) for reducing the torsional response of the superstructure. The effect of the isolator eccentricity on the base responses is more than that of the superstructure responses.
The angle of incidence of near-fault ground motions with respect to the principal direction of a structure moderately influences the effectiveness of the base isolation (using the VFPS).
The corner displacement magnification increases with the increase in the superstructure eccentricity and the isolation period of the VFPS, whereas it decreases with the increase in the torsional to lateral frequency ratio of the superstructure. On the other hand, it first increases, attains a maximum value, and then decreases with the increase in the initial time period of the VFPS.
